newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain's Rato nudges Socialists on 1997 budget.
newsitem.headline: Spain's Rato nudges Socialists on 1997 budget.

text.p: Finance Minister Rodrigo Rato, opening the parliamentary debate on a 1997 budget that will make or break Spain's EMU chances, urged the opposition Socialists on Tuesday to look for points of agreement with the government.

Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar's conservative administration is guaranteed to win the vote on the budget thanks to support from its Catalan allies, but Rato said it still wanted the main opposition party to cooperate.

"The Socialist group's position is important," Rato told parliament. "I hope in the name of the government that at this time...we will be able to hear about the instruments they think are required for the common goal of cutting unemployment and joining the (EU) economic and monetary union."
"I believe there can be concrete issues on which we can agree," he added.
Only hours before Rato opened the budget session, Aznar criticised his Socialist predecessor Felipe Gonzalez for deciding to skip the debate on a 1997 budget.

Gonzalez's Socialists and the Communist-led United Left have introduced motions rejecting the budget, but it is guaranteed a safe passage on the combined votes of the ruling conservatives, their Catalan nationalist allies and smaller regional parties.

Aznar and his aides blamed disarray in Socialist ranks for the main opposition party's decision to give the floor to two of its top economic men rather than to Gonzalez in the three-day debate that started on Tuesday.
"Gonzalez's absence shows the opposition is incapable of providing an alternative," Aznar told reporters.

The Socialist leader's silence could fuel the arguments of foes to his right and to his left who say the same corruption scandals and charges of a "dirty war" on Basque rebels that cost him his job continue to gag him now he is in opposition.
Gonzalez, who ruled Spain for 13 years until May and was the architect of Spain's 1986 entry to the then European Community, rejected the government's criticism as meddling in his party.
"We are the ones who decide our strategy and our participation and we allocate (tasks), not others," he told reporters.

Aznar's ministers hope the austere budget package will allow them to meet economic and monetary union (EMU) criteria during 1997, the year on which would-be participants in the single currency will be tested for fitness.
The 1997 budget slashes total spending growth to just 1.7 percent by cutting or freezing outlays in all sectors except for pensions, health and regional transfers.
With inflation expected at 2.6 percent next year, it is the toughest budget since Spain's return to democracy in 1975.
